claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination broadened antigen display, increasing the fraction of tumor proteins represented in the immunopeptidome.

evidence.quote: | Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination |
A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.

claims.caveat: This report summarizes pooled mouse experiments and proposed mechanisms; effects may vary by model and may not map one-to-one to human tumors.

claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination induced a type I interferon state and increased PD-L1 pathway activity, supporting a rationale for combining with checkpoint blockade.

evidence.quote: | Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors |
| PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue | 2.4x | 1.0x | Checkpoint axis became more targetable |
PD-L1 pathway activity also increases, creating a rationale for combining with checkpoint blockade.

claims.caveat: Mechanistic readouts were not uniformly strongest across all tested settings, so the magnitude and generality of these pathways may depend on the tumor model.

claims.claim: Type I interferon signaling was required for the sensitization effect, because blocking IFNAR1 eliminated the observed benefit.

evidence.quote: Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.
Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.

claims.caveat: This requirement was shown within the experimental systems summarized here; translation to human tumors may differ and would require prospective clinical testing.

claims.claim: In a retrospective metastatic patient cohort receiving ICI treatment, prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination was associated with improved survival.

evidence.quote: - Translational arm: a retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.
| Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment |
- The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.

claims.caveat: Because the human comparison is retrospective with variable vaccination timing and heterogeneous tumor types, the survival association should not be interpreted as causal.
